content: Hardcore gamers want performance. Casual gamers want convenience. Google Stadia tried to please both but failed.
My Stadia is lowering the volume on headphones. This is a negative experience and needs fixing.
Darksiders Genesis review: I give it 4 out of 5. It's a good game to play on stadia.
Google Stadia review: Consoles and gaming PCs are safe for now, since it is not the best experience.
I'm surprisingly impressed with Google Stadia! It is not perfect but performs well.
Good night and good bye Stadia. You brought joy into so many early mornings and evenings during the pandemic.
For like a year I was a big Stadia fan. I loved the virtually free console and modern games, even though I got roasted.
Bottom left gamepad was getting good reviews, and I'm a gamepad addict, so I got it.
I'm interested in Stadia. I'll think again when I see some 5 star reviews of it.
Many reviews mention latency issues because all games are streamed through the cloud.
Critics said Google Stadia was dead on arrival when the review embargo lifted at its launch.
Stadia represents a loss of gaming consumers rights to privacy and their rights to enjoy games.
I have read a number of positive reviews about Stadia. In 2020 Stadia will become attractive for casual gamers.
Early reviews suggest that Stadia might change how we play games in the future.
I've used Stadia for a couple of months under the free offer, and only with third party games.
The fact that lag and input latency were referenced in so many negative reviews is a huge problem for Stadia.
From the reports and reviews I have read Stadia is not competing well with the others. There are several reasons why.
A fluid gameplay on Stadia depends A LOT on your internet connection. It has to be very fast and very stable.
It is bound to have an effect! If people spend more cycles playing through Stadia and less through consoles.
The recent reviews and details show that Stadia will be launching with 12 games only and missing features.
I don't have my controller yet, but I tested Destiny 2 at work. I was pleasantly surprised by its responsiveness.
The Digital Foundry review shows image quality and latency comparisons. The 4K marketing is a gimmick it looks blurry.
I just need iPad Pro and iPhone support, and then I'm completely on board with Stadia.
Stadia needs exclusive games that can only be played on the platform, not just ports from other systems.
I'm loving Stadia! No more consoles for me. It is so easy to pick up and play on any device.
I'd like more aggressive discounts for Pro members. Digital divide forces me to stick with consoles and Steam.
I'm waiting for wireless controller support. Steam integration would be interesting, considering the GeForceNOW situation.
I am very interested in Stadia, but it doesn't have any games that I want to play right now.
It is weird that no one seems to complain about Stadia availability in only a few countries.
Wireless controller, linking, and input lag are the only things bothering me. Other than that, it's smooth.
All the youtube reviews I saw were mostly positive. For casual games, I think it'll be fine.
The success depends on the availability of supporting infrastructure in the future. The idea is there.
After playing Destiny, it's nice to grab my laptop and sort through my inventory on the couch.
Stadia needs exclusive games that make it worth investing in the platform, like tent pole exclusives.
People complaining about input lag probably have local network issues that are outside of Google's control.
Fired up Rise of the Tomb Raider and it runs smooth as silk with my x-box wireless controller. Love it!
The platform is impressive, and it will continue to grow. Google's ecosystem as a whole is developing nicely.
It's poor quality on my Chromebook and PC because it doesn't support VP9. You need modern hardware.
I have frame loss and terrible mouse input. Incognito tab improved it, but there is still frame loss.
I've been pleasantly surprised by Stadia. Steam World games are fun and run well with strong wireless.
Visual quality, input lag, and freezing are frequent and make some games borderline unplayable for me.
Images from Stadia are blurry and look bad. Images from the One X are significantly better for me.
Stadia will be an upgrade for me, and I'm sure they will improve the service. Graphics look washed out.
What a disappointment. This is pseudo-4k. They shouldn't be allowed to advertise like this, misleadingly.
This review isn't terrible. Tomb Raider ran at 4K, so it was up to the game developer to implement it.
Doom Eternal was confirmed to be running on a native 4K 60FPS. I'm not worried about this.
I don't play games where latency is important so I don't mind it. I only pay attention for visual fidelity.
Wired is still better even for streaming service. Google is far up on their own ____ for claiming otherwise.
Internet latency is not something they can mitigate, and it is not possible in most countries.
I think it would have been more interesting to compare input latency between Stadia and PS4/XBOX consoles.
I think this is probably the best implementation of a bad idea I've seen to date for streaming games.
I am impressed, but knowing Google, they might kill this off in 3-4 years and discontinue support.
Cyberpunk runs with great frame rate and load times but I have audio lag on Chromecast Ultra currently.
Google has delivered with Cyberpunk 2077 on Stadia, making Nvidia look bad with their GFN troubles.
I love the service and I'm impressed at how smooth it runs on my phone's data after the beta.
